awd_titl_txt: DIMENSIONS: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: The evolution of pollination syndrome diversity in Penstemon
awd_abstract_narration:
Ecosystem health and productivity depend on co-evolved species interactions. In terrestrial ecosystems a key interaction is between flowers and pollinators, and changes in the relative abundances of different pollinators (e.g., bees, birds) are thought to impose selective pressures that can shift floral pollination strategies and shape flowering plant communities. However, multiple forces may act to constrain the ability of a flowering plant lineage to evolve a new pollination strategy under changing environmental conditions. This research will model the rate of pollination strategy transitions in the largest flowering plant genus endemic to North America (Penstemon), and will determine both ecological and genetic processes that constrain and shape the rate of pollination strategy diversification. Understanding the forces that maintain diversity in pollination strategies informs food security and agricultural management issues.

The research integrates phylogenetic, ecological, and genetic approaches to understand the processes that determine pollination diversity. The research will test whether Penstemon has reached an evolutionary equilibrium in the relative frequencies of bee and hummingbird pollination syndromes. Additionally, the planned experiments will determine ecological and genetic processes responsible for asymmetries in pollination syndrome transitions, and in syndrome-specific speciation, and extinction rates. Field experiments will test whether interactions among floral traits constrain shifts from hummingbird to bee pollination. Genetic experiments will test whether loss-of-function mutations critical for shifts to hummingbird pollination also constrain reverse shifts from hummingbird to bee pollination. The integration of these experimental approaches will elucidate processes that determine pollination syndrome diversity in plant community assemblages.

por.por_cntn:
This project was part of a collaborative effort that focused on bee- versus hummingbird-pollinated species in the wildflower genus, Penstemon. The overarching aim was to better understand patterns and processes of complex trait evolution. One critical goal of biologists is to determine the processes that shape trait diversity in nature. By focusing on closely related Penstemon species that differ in pollinators, some species adapted to bees and others to hummingbirds for pollination, the researchers gained novel insight into how pollinator adaptation affects diversification (speciation and extinction). They found that during Penstemon diversification, hummingbird-adapted species evolve from bee-adapted ancestors at a higher rate that the reverse. Yet overall hummingbird-adapted species are relatively rare. The researchers discovered that this is because Penstemon lineages that are hummingbird adapted diversify at a much lower rate than lineages that are bee-adapted, leaving those hummingbird-adapted lineages species-poor compared to their bee-adapted counterparts. A second fundamental goal of biologists is to understand the connection between the genotype of an organism and its phenotype (or trait expression), especially for complex traits like flowers where precise combinations of color, shape, scent, and nectar reward lead to important flower-pollinator interactions. Using combinations of genetic and genomic tools, across field and greenhouse experiments, the researchers discovered that complex floral trait combinations in Penstemon required for bee- versus hummingbird-adaptation are controlled by a small number of genetically variable sites across the genome (perhaps only 20). What is especially surprising about their results is that these critical regions of the genome are scattered broadly across all Penstemon chromosomes instead of being tightly linked to in one or few chromosomal regions, providing new insights into how complex traits might initially evolve.

This project provided critical genomic, transcriptomic, and methodological resources for the biological community. It additionally provided excellent training in experimental design, genetic and genomic techniques, molecular laboratory techniques, scientific communication, and manuscript preparation to five graduate students (three PhD and two master’s), thirteen undergraduate students, and two research technicians. The graduate students included one international student, four women, and two first-generation college students. The undergraduate students included seven who were recruited to the project through institutional programs at the University of Kansas aimed at increasing participation in research from underrepresented populations in STEM fields. All graduate and undergraduate students participating in this project who have graduated have gone on to join the research workforce in industry or academic settings. The research team was engaged in outreach activities during the funding period that enhanced public understanding of the importance of biological diversity, adaptation, and plant-animal interactions to ecological and agricultural functions.
